gameDetails.matchup: San Antonio Spurs vs Golden State Warriors
gameDetails.venue: Frost Bank Center, San Antonio, TX

recentPerformance.hitRate: Spurs 8-2 record, first home loss coming

keyFactors.title: Spurs Elite Home Record
keyFactors.description: Spurs entered 6-0 at Frost Bank Center with dominant +17.3 point differential at home. Warriors were 0-6 on the road entering this game.

keyFactors.title: Warriors Road Struggles
keyFactors.description: Golden State came in having lost 6 straight road games, looking completely lost away from Chase Center. Major travel/fatigue concerns.

keyFactors.title: Wembanyama's Dominance
keyFactors.description: Victor Wembanyama averaging 26.2 PPG, 12.8 RPG with elite rim protection. Expected to dominate Warriors' undersized frontcourt.

keyFactors.title: Castle's Emergence
keyFactors.description: Rookie Stephon Castle showing impressive playmaking, averaging 12.8 PPG, 6.4 APG in last 5 games. Added secondary ball-handler threat.

keyFactors.title: Warriors Defensive Issues
keyFactors.description: Golden State allowing 118.4 PPG on the road, ranking 26th in defensive rating away from home. Vulnerable to Spurs' balanced attack.

riskFactors: Stephen Curry capable of explosive scoring nights
Spurs relatively small spread could be tight game
Warriors desperate for road win after 6-game skid
Young Spurs team vulnerable to veteran Warriors' experience

curry.impact: Season-high 46 points, including 22 in Q3, completely took over the game

wembanyama.impact: Historic triple-double with Castle, but couldn't stop Curry's onslaught

castle.impact: First career triple-double alongside Wembanyama, but defense couldn't contain Warriors

butler.impact: Critical secondary scoring for Warriors, 28 points took pressure off Curry

quarterBreakdown.description: Spurs started hot, Wembanyama dominated early with 10 points. Warriors kept it close with Curry's 8 points.
Spurs extended lead to 16 points midway through quarter. Castle and Wembanyama clicking, looked in full control.
DISASTER. Curry exploded for 22 points in quarter, going 5-9 from three and 9-9 from FT line. Warriors' 45-point quarter erased entire deficit and took 8-point lead.
Spurs fought back but couldn't overcome Curry's dominance. Warriors held on for 5-point win, covering Spurs -3.5 spread easily.

gameResults.turningPoint: Q3: Curry's 22-point explosion. Warriors outscored Spurs 45-25 in third quarter, turning 12-point deficit into 8-point lead. Game completely flipped.
gameResults.gamePace: Fast-paced game with 245 combined points. Both teams shot efficiently, but Warriors' third quarter surge was unstoppable.
gameResults.teamOffense: Spurs had balanced attack with Wembanyama (31), Castle (23), but couldn't stop Warriors' Curry (46) and Butler (28) duo. Defense failed.

whatWentWrong.title: Curry Nuclear Explosion
whatWentWrong.description: Stephen Curry's 46 points (22 in Q3 alone) was completely game-breaking. Went 15-16 from FT line and hit 5 threes in third quarter. No defensive answer for vintage Curry performance.

whatWentWrong.title: Third Quarter Collapse
whatWentWrong.description: 45-25 third quarter for Warriors erased entire 12-point halftime lead. Spurs' defense completely fell apart when it mattered most. Historically bad defensive quarter.

whatWentWrong.title: Jimmy Butler's Supporting Role
whatWentWrong.description: Butler's 28 points alongside Curry provided elite 1-2 punch. Took pressure off Curry and gave Warriors multiple scoring threats Spurs couldn't contain.

whatWentWrong.title: Historic Triple-Doubles Wasted
whatWentWrong.description: Wembanyama (31-15-10) and Castle (23-10-10) became first Spurs teammates with triple-doubles in same game, yet lost. Offensive production was there, defense failed catastrophically.

whatWentWrong.title: Warriors Desperation Factor
whatWentWrong.description: Warriors entered on 6-game road losing streak, desperately needed this win. Played with urgency and intensity that exceeded Spurs' effort. Underestimated their motivation.

statisticalContext.expectedMargin: Spurs win by 5-7 points based on home dominance
statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Warriors' 125 points = 90th percentile road scoring performance

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: This was NOT normal variance—this was Curry going nuclear. His 46-point performance (season-high) and 22-point Q3 is not predictable or repeatable. Model couldn't account for one of greatest shooters ever having vintage performance. Defense had no counter to elite Curry night.

closingLineValue.verdict: Decent CLV (+5 cents). Line moved slightly toward Spurs as money came in. Early price captured small edge, but Curry's explosion nullified everything.

keyTakeaways: Cannot model elite individual performances: Curry's 46 points was outlier event that invalidated all statistical edges
Home dominance means nothing against generational talent: Spurs' 6-0 home record couldn't withstand vintage Curry performance
Third quarter defense collapsed: 45-25 Warriors Q3 erased 12-point halftime lead. One bad quarter cost the entire game
Triple-doubles don't guarantee wins: Wembanyama and Castle's historic performances were wasted by defensive failures
Desperation factor matters: Warriors' 6-game road skid created urgency we underestimated. Wounded team played like it.
2U stake on small spread was aggressive: -3.5 is coin flip territory. Should've sized down to 1U given variance potential
verdict: Painful loss. Curry's nuclear 46 (with 22 in Q3) was unpredictable outlier. Spurs' defense collapsed when it mattered. While logic was sound (home dominance vs road-struggling Warriors), we can't model generational talent having career-level nights. 2U stake was too aggressive for -3.5 spread. Grade: D
